events.name: at beginning, setup links. You can't link instances of the same object. So, create a link object at the same location of each object and link them together.

events.comment: at the player to the link data

events.name: if the destination is reached or button is clicked, clear path, unlick the players past location and link to new location
if button is clicked, move the target to the next square and move the player to that square

events.comment: unlink the target object, increase it's place varaible by 1 use mod() to loop back to the first tile.
move the target, link the target's new position

The next 2 groups look the same but the 2nd one is used to handle when the player goes from the last tile to the first tile.
Say the players on a tile with an ID of 7 and the target is on 10. Then you select the tiles  >= 7 and <=10
but if the player is near the end of the sequence like 20 and the target is on 5 then you want to select the tiles >= 20 OR <= 5
The differnce is the and & or. In the 2nd case, A number can't be both >= 20 and <=5 So, we use an OR
If the player is on a tile with an ID less than the target's ID then select the tiles between the 2 locations and move the player

It picks the tiles in between for 2 reasons. To highlight them and to select the tiles in front of the player so on a small board it doesn't move backwards if the move was large enough. The mover always wants to take the shortest path. While it's unlikely to happen on a larger board, it is possible on a smaller board.

If the ID of the space the player is on is higher than the ID of the space the target's tile ID then the player is at the end of the tile sequence and the target is at the beginning. So, pick the tiles whose ID is greater than the player's OR less than the target

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: LinkTools
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Conditions to use Linked Objects as a graph and a path finding movement behavior.
description: * "Can reach through links" conditions, useful to check if an object is linked to another through one or more other linked objects.
* a path finding movement behavior that uses objects links (instead of obstacles for the other behavior)
For instance, it can be helpful for grid-based games like:
* Point and click (bypass obstacles with a predetermined polygonal chain)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelSpriteButton
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.
description: The button can be customized with a background for each state and a label. It handles user interactions and a simple condition can be used to check if it is clicked.
There are ready-to-use buttons in the asset-store [menu buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: The finite state machine used internally by the button object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ButtonFSM

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

eventsFunctions.name: IsPressed

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is currently being pressed outside with mouse or touch.

eventsFunctions.description: the touch id that is using the button or 0 if none.
eventsFunctions.name: TouchId

eventsBasedObjects.description: A button that can be customized.
eventsBasedObjects.name: PanelSpriteButton

events.comment:
Create one background instance for of each state.
Only the instance for the current state is shown.
Place the label over the backgrounds.
Show the right background accordingly to the new state.

Children instances must be resized when the button size change:
- backgrounds for each state are resized to take the full dimensions of the button
- the label is put back at the center of the button

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.
